memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2164

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the vehicle and traffic law, in relation to penalties for
procuring alcoholic beverages for persons under the age of twenty-one

PURPOSE:
Provides additional penalties for persons who purchase
alcohol for others who are under the age of twenty-one.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section one amends subdivision .3 of § 510 of the Vehicle and Traffic
law by adding new paragraph 1, which provides for the suspension of a
person's drivers license upon conviction of §65-a of the ABC
(procuring alcoholic beverages for a person under age twenty-one).
Such suspension may be up to 90 days for a first violation and up to
180 days for a second or subsequent violation and is in addition to
the penalties provided for in §65-a of the ABC.

Section two establishes the effective date.

EXISTING LAW:
Current law provides for a fine of $200 or by
imprisonment for not more than five days, or both, for those who
procure alcohol for persons under the age of twenty-one.

JUSTIFICATION:
Currently, someone who purchases alcohol for a person
under the age of twenty-one is, upon conviction, subject to a fine of
$200 and/or up to five days imprisonment. According to the National
Highway Traffic Safety Administration, three teenagers die every day
when they drink and drive and the CDC estimates another six die each
day from other alcohol-related causes. In light of these figures, a
small tine imposed on someone who supplies underage persons with
alcohol seems staggeringly insignificant. Under this legislation,
such person would face suspension of his driver's license, in
addition to the penalties already provided for in §65-a of the
Alcoholic Beverage Control law.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.5460 of 2003-04 - Passed Senate
S.6530 of 2006 - Health
S.1149 of 2007 - Passed Senate; 2008 - Transportation
s.1580 of 2009-10 - Transportation

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
